sense.name: stretch to the utmost, causing stress or injury
sense.commentary:
NP1[+agent] STRAIN NP2[+object] (PP[direction,location])
NOTE: Compare to sense 2, this sense refers to straining an object where sense 2 refers to straining to do an action. eg. 'straining one's back' vs 'straining to lift something'. Thus if a PP is used without NP2, NP2 is implied. Includes metaphorical uses.
sense.examples: You are straining my patience. Calvin strained his back lifting the drywall. Failing to see his tail, he strained his neck further. Other events that strained the relationship during that period were the Cox report. Workers are instucted not to strain their eyes for diamonds.

sense.name: exert great effort at an action, without necessarily causing harm to the doer
sense.commentary:
NP1[+animate] STRAIN VP[infinitve] (NP2[-concrete])
NOTE: compare to sense 1. This focus of this sense is the exertion, to perform an action, as opposed to the harm inflicted upon the object of the action. eg. 'straining to see' vs 'straining your eyes'
sense.examples: He strained to hear what was being said. She strained to answer the questions she had on Shandra. The 302 horses under the Benz's hood are practically in a lather, straining to get free.

sense.name: pass through a strainer
sense.examples: Then she strained the mixture, using a piece of cloth.
